node.title: Visas offered for Ukrainian New Zealanders' families
node.description: Parents and wider family members will be able to join Ukrainians in New Zealand under a new policy covering about 4000 people.

node.title: Dilworth School advances abuse redress plans
node.description: Dilworth School is progressing with compensation plans for survivors of sexual abuse at the boys' school.

node.title: The CDC could lose access to key data to track COVID-19
node.description: "We are the compiler of the data, but we do not have the authority to collect it," CDC Director Dr. Rochelle Walensky told CBS News.

node.title: Judge permanently blocks release of Bob Saget's autopsy records
node.description: Saget, 65, was found dead​ January 9 in a room at the Ritz Carlton in Orlando.

node.title: Slight relief for West Coast DHB as new midwives fill critical gaps
node.description: Two new midwives are expected to start work in Greymouth soon - a bright spot for the West Coast DHB in trying to recruit staff across a number of areas.

node.title: 'This is their home': Dunedin sea lions notch up breeding record
node.description: In the most successful breeding season since the sea lions returned to Dunedin shores, 20 pups were tagged from St Kilda to Warrington.

node.title: Commerce Commission approves 2degrees Vocus merger
node.description: The merger of telecommunications companies 2degrees and Vocus has cleared a major hurdle with the Commerce Commission giving its blessing.

node.title: Opposition parties give government 'fail' grade over temporary fuel tax cuts
node.description: Opposition parties across the political spectrum have given the government a 'fail' grade over its temporary fuel tax cuts. Audio

node.title: Expert emphasises Covid-19 vaccine booster is essential, not extra
node.description: The Covid-19 vaccine booster needs a rebrand because it sounds like it is an "optional extra", says a public health expert, as worry rises about stalling rates.

node.title: Kyiv's mayor on potential for chemical weapons attack: "Russia doesn't have rules"
node.description: "With any price, they want to win," Kyiv Mayor Vitali Klitschko said.

node.title: "We are against war": Russians in Atlanta show solidarity with Ukraine
node.description: "I feel pain. I cry a lot right now," one woman said. "At this moment, the people of Ukraine are defending their freedom and country, at the cost of their lives."

node.title: January 6 defendant says he will plead guilty to assaulting officers
node.description: The judge agreed with the defense that Lucas Denney had been mistreated, but he delayed his arraignment until Thursday.

node.title: Five lessons to remember from Covid-19 impacts on the housing market
node.description: The past two years for the housing market will be remembered as a "bizarre period" with measures designed to smooth volatility generating significant ups and downs instead.

node.title: The best places to live in the U.S. in 2022
node.description: Did your city make the cut?

node.title: Sex work under the red light pushes people into risky business, poverty
node.description: Sex workers have a long history of trading under a red light, but the new phase of the coronavirus pandemic has left many struggling for financial survival as vulnerable people in danger.

node.title: EV and hybrid sales going 'gangbusters' as motorists grapple with fuel prices
node.description: Hybrid and electric vehicles are flying out the doors of used car dealerships, with motorists looking to slash their fuel bills as prices rise.

node.title: Māori Health Authority to begin funding services
node.description: The Māori Health Authority has received funding and is set up enough to begin funding health services, the government has announced.

node.title: Public transport fares to be halved, fuel taxes and road user charges reduced
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says the reductions will be in place for three months. One petrol company says changes will be made to fuel price immediately. Audio

node.title: Christchurch terror attacks emboldened far-right extremists - report
node.description: Online Islamophobia was reported 18 times as often in the immediate aftermath of the attacks and real-world Islamophobia quadrupled, a new report has found.

node.title: Buyers fear overpaying despite house prices holding - report
node.description: The slowing in the housing market is becoming more pronounced, as a growing supply of houses, unaffordability, and resistance to high prices takes effect.

node.title: Hurricanes ready to roll again in Super Rugby Pacific
node.description: The Covid-hit Hurricanes are confident they will be able to play their Super Rugby Pacific game against the Chiefs this weekend, despite limited preparation.

node.title: England lose again at World Cup
node.description: England's title defence in the Women's Cricket World Cup has suffered another blow after losing to South Africa.

node.title: Cricket and Kilikiti, Ross Taylor talks about finding the best of both worlds
node.description: New Zealand farewelled its highest international run-scorer and a true gentleman of the game when Ross Taylor signalled his retirement from international cricket.

node.title: Ukraine war: 'Sky turned red' as missiles hit Lviv military base
node.description: Witnesses to a deadly Russian attack on a Ukrainian military base have told how "the sky turned red" as missiles struck the site near the Polish border.

node.title: How sanctions have changed everyday life in Russia
node.description: The US, UK and EU have imposed unprecedented financial penalties on Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, and hundreds of companies have left the country.

node.title: Covid-19: South Island healthcare providers prepare for Omicron wave
node.description: Some general practices and community health providers say they're already stretched and are bracing for cases to peak over next few weeks.

node.title: FIANZ satisfied with govt response to Royal Commission but still 'work to be done'
node.description: The government has scored well in a report card about how it is implementing 44 recommendations from the Royal Commission into the 15 March mosque attacks. Audio

node.title: Māori social workers slam Oranga Tamariki for being 'on the back foot'
node.description: Two leading Māori social workers are scathing of Oranga Tamariki's attempts to fix huge gaps in sexual violence crisis support for children.

node.title: 'Good news' that road cost cuts won't affect infrastructure funds
node.description: The government's latest announcement on relieving cost pressures on the road are being welcomed, with particular applause for the fact they will not come at the cost of investment in infrastructure.

node.title: Help in a crisis or 'not the best choice': New Zealanders react to fuel tax cuts
node.description: Kiwis have mixed views about how the cuts in fuel excise duty and public transport fares will affect them. Audio
